## Description {#details}

This represents a position within a bitstream.

There may be multiple independent cursors reading within one bitstream, each maintaining their own local state.

Definition at line 79 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/bitstream/bitstreamreader-h">BitstreamReader.h</a>.

<SectionDefinition>

## Public Member Typedefs

### word&#95;t {#a844fc5e45f6ac94e7da1f7f5a94dc604}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>using llvm::SimpleBitstreamCursor::word&#95;t =  size&#95;t</>}>
This is the current data we have pulled from the stream but have not returned to the client.

This is specifically and intentionally defined to follow the word size of the host machine for efficiency. We use <a href="#a844fc5e45f6ac94e7da1f7f5a94dc604">word&#95;t</a> in places that are aware of this to make it perfectly explicit what is going on.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/bitstream/bitstreamreader-h/#l00089">89</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/bitstream/bitstreamreader-h">BitstreamReader.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

Get a pointer into the bitstream at the specified bit offset.

### BitsInCurWord {#a5915e0fb546d008f2e9a42d4aaf477e8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned llvm::SimpleBitstreamCursor::BitsInCurWord = 0">
This is the number of bits in CurWord that are valid.

This is always from &#91;0...bits&#95;of(size&#95;t)-1&#93; inclusive.
